title: Practice Exercise
description:
Build a **Movie Rating Analyzer** that processes movie data and generates insights. **Requirements:** - **Data Structure**: Each movie is a tuple: (id, title, year, [ratings])
  • ratings is a list of user ratings (1-10)
    • - **Create sample data** for at least 6 movies - **Calculate statistics**:
  • Average rating per movie - Overall average across all movies - Highest and lowest rated movies
    • - **Filter movies**:
  • Highly rated (avg >= 8.0) - Poorly rated (avg < 6.0) - Recent movies (year >= 2020)
    • - **Analyze ratings**:
  • Movies with most ratings (participation) - Movies with most consistent ratings (low variance) - Distribution by decade
    • - **Generate reports**:
  • Top 5 movies - Recommendations (highly rated recent movies) - Rating distribution chart
    • **Example Output:** 
    === Movie Rating Analyzer ===

Loaded 6 movies

Top Rated Movies:
1. The Shawshank Redemption (1994) - 9.3 ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐
2. The Dark Knight (2008) - 9.0 ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐
3. Inception (2010) - 8.8 ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

Recommendations (Recent + Highly Rated):
- Dune (2021) - 8.5
- Everything Everywhere (2022) - 8.9

Rating Distribution:
9-10: ██████ 3 movies
7-8:  ████ 2 movies
5-6:  ██ 1 movie

hints.text: For average: sum(ratings)/len(ratings). For comprehension: [(title, sum(ratings)/len(ratings)) for (id, title, year, ratings) in movies]. For filtering: [... for ... in movies if condition]. For AND conditions: if cond1 and cond2. For sorting: list.sort(key=lambda x: x[1], reverse=True). For slicing top N: list[:N].

commonMistakes.correction: Add : at the end of the line
